sentences.sentence: Oil and natural gas prices have risen considerably over the past nine months.
The price of Western Canadian Select (WSC) crude, the benchmark price for Alberta oil, averaged US$45.13 per barrel in January.
By the first week of October, it had increased to $64.78 per barrel.

Other things equal, an almost $20 jump in price should stimulate economic activity in Canada's oil sector.But the price of West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude, the benchmark U.S. oil price, also rose over the same period - from US$59.04 to US$75.65 - so while higher oil prices are a tailwind for Canadian oil and gas companies, absent policy change in Canada (see pipeline restrictions, corporate tax rates, etc.
), oil and gas investors likely will continue to favour U.S.-based companies that are also beneficiaries of higher oil prices.Why?
Because investment decisions in the private sector are ultimately determined by the expected future profitability of alternative capital expenditure projects, appropriately adjusted for risk.
Corporate and private investors in the energy sector will invest in projects located where expected risk-adjusted returns are highest.

Investing in the U.S. has been and will continue to be a compelling alternative to investing in Canada for energy companies and institutional investors, and the price of WCS relative to WTI remains only one factor influencing expected profitability.Investors generally don't disclose their expectations about the future profitability of alternative investments.
But they can be inferred from financial valuation metrics, including a company's price-to-earnings ratio or its price-to-sales ratio.

If investors are willing to pay more for a share of Company A's stock than for a share of Company B's stock per dollar of current earnings or current sales, it's presumably because investors expect the future earnings and sales of Company A to grow faster than those of Company B.Peter Shawn Taylor: What comes after the gas tax?

(https://financialpost.com/opinion/peter-shawn-taylor-what-comes-after-the-gas-tax)Opinion: Europe made its energy bed and now must sleep in it - shivering(https://financialpost.com/opinion/opinion-europe-made-its-energy-bed-and-now-must-sleep-in-it-shivering)Philip Cross: If oil and gas are dead, why are exports booming?

(https://financialpost.com/opinion/philip-cross-if-oil-and-gas-are-dead-why-are-exports-booming)In a new Fraser Institute study(https://www.fraserinstitute.org/studies/investment-outlook-for-the-canadian-and-us-oil-and-gas-sectors?utm_source=Media-Releases&;utm_campaign=Investment-Outlook-for-Cdn-and-US-Oil-and-Gas-Sectors&;utm_medium=Media&;utm_content=Learn_More&;utm_term=550) co-authored with the Institute's Joel Emes, we compare several financial valuation metrics (price-to-earnings, price-to-sales and price-to-book value) for a portfolio of publicly-traded Canadian oil and gas companies with those of a portfolio of U.S. oil and gas companies.
From 2011 to 2020, each of the ratios for the portfolio of Canadian oil and gas companies fell relative to its counterpart in the U.S. portfolio.

This result is consistent with expressions of concern by executives of Canadian oil and gas companies that Canada is a less and less profitable location for capital investment compared to jurisdictions in the U.S. - and notwithstanding the rise in the WCS price relative to the WTI price from 2017 to 2019.The most recent valuation metrics, those for 2021, do provide a more mixed picture.

Although the price-to-sales and price-to-book value ratios for Canadian-headquartered oil and gas companies increased relative to those for their U.S.-headquartered counterparts, the price-to-earnings ratio fell.

Perhaps the outlook for a less favourable regulatory and corporate tax environment under the Biden administration has reduceed the expected future profitability of U.S. oil and gas companies compared to what it was under the lighter regulation introduced by the Trump administration.With the rising prices of gasoline and natural gas, there's growing public concern in the U.S. surrounding President Biden's ambitious plans to replace fossil fuels with green energy alternatives.

It's possible, but far from certain, that Biden will get some portion of his green energy program passed into law, notwithstanding opposition from key Democrat senators, most notably Joe Manchin of West Virginia.
Still, since a future Republican administration may well reverse Biden's policies, tying the financial sustainability of Canada's oil and gas sector to the vagaries of U.S. politics remains risky.

If Canadians believe a competitive oil and gas sector is in the national interest, policies affecting the industry should be consistent with that belief.Steven Globerman is an analyst at the Fraser Institute.
@COPYRIGHT=Â© 2021 Postmedia Network Inc. All rights reserved.

documents.result_message: Our detector is moderately confident that the text is written entirely by a human.

Corporate and private investors in the energy sector will invest in projects located where expected risk-adjusted returns are highest.
